lg.l: A legend, my friend, they relate A legend … they relate. Wilson retells a traditional narrative of Ngāti Tūwharetoa, an iwi (tribe) of the central North Island. Her source appears to be Ferdinand von Hochstetter, New Zealand (Stuttgart: Cotta, 1867). of these fire-guarded mountains,
Three mountains Three mountains. The mountains of Ruapehu, Tongariro, and Ngauruhoe, which dominate the central plateau of the North Island. that rise in the silent and untrodden forest,
Forbidden to white foot, and held by the Maori thrice-sacred. Forbidden … thrice-sacred. The three mountains of the central plateau are tapu (sacred) to Ngāti Tūwharetoa.
One mountain, the greatest, The greatest. Mount Ruapehu, the largest active volcano in Aotearoa New Zealand. arises in snow-sheeted splendour,
Far seen on the plains, like a white ship blown hither and stranded,
From the ice-fields that gleam to the dance of the southern Aurora;

And one wears the veil of volcano; Veil of volcano. Mount Ngauruhoe, a distinct volcanic cone that is nevertheless part of the Tongariro volcanic centre. and one looks a ruin. Ruin. Presumably Mount Tongariro, which consists of multiple volcanic cones.

In the ages far past came a chief from the isles of the west wave Chief from the isles of the west wave. Ngātoroirangi, a powerful high priest on the Te Arawa waka (voyaging canoe), which brought Ngāti Tūwharetoa from Hawaiki to Aotearoa.
To see these wild peaks; and with him came the slave, Ngaru-hoé.
They sought to ascend, but the death-wind blew cold from the glacier:
And the sleep of its breath overcame Ngaru-hoé, the faithful.
Then the chief cried in anguish—“Oh, Sisters! come hither! I perish!”

. . . . The sisters Sisters. The sisters of Ngātoroirangi, Kuiwai and Haungaroa, who are located on the offshore volcanic island of Whakaari (White Island) in Hochstetter’s narrative. arose in their sun-lighted vales of Hawaii—
Snatched fire from the altar, and flew o’er the ripples of ocean.
They stumbled in haste, and the holy fire fell from their fingers,
And burns to this day in wild geyser, or smouldering volcano. Geyser … volcano. The fire brought to Ngātoroirangi explains the prevalence of geothermal activity across parts of the North Island.
So they rescued the chief; and the fire to his bosom returning,
Hand in hand they fled fast down the cliffs of the rushing Waikato. Waikato. The Waikato, the longest river in New Zealand, rises from the slopes of Mount Ruapehu.
By the light of the peak, by the smoke of the red-burning island,
Over ripple and reef, till they reached the hearth-stone of Hawaii. Hawaii. The journey back to Hawaiki (Hawaii) is an alteration to Hochstetter’s narrative.
But no footstep returning awakens the slave, Ngaru-hoé.
So peaceful he sleeps in the shade of the thrice-smitten mountain.
